text: We are having a difficult time nailing down the right strategy for optimizing underperforming article-based content -- do you just holistically edit for search intent + overall content quality and hope for the best? Are you editing specific/singular aspects of the article at a time, like only title tag/intro/headers/links/structure/etc.? Would love to hear about strategies that have worked!

elements.text: We are having a difficult time nailing down the right strategy for optimizing underperforming article-based content -- do you just holistically edit for search intent + overall content quality and hope for the best? Are you editing specific/singular aspects of the article at a time, like only title tag/intro/headers/links/structure/etc.? Would love to hear about strategies that have worked!

text:
I usually take the approach of working on the title, URL, header structure and overall content. For example, when I use <http://usetopic.com|Topic>, I place the existing content into their grader to see what the current score is.

From there, I read the existing ranking content and compare it to my content to look for opportunities. I then update the headers as needed and the actual content.

95% of the time, we see an improvement in search rankings within 3 weeks

text:
_What_ you need to do depends on _why_ something is "underperforming." All the on-page optimization in the world (probably) won't help you if you're a small fish competing against <http://Forbes.com|Forbes.com> or <http://WebMD.com|WebMD.com>.

Before you pour a ton of resources into on-page improvements, I'd dig through the search results for the topic you're targeting and see who owns that space—and why (e.g., super powerful domain, niche site speaking to their expertise, long-form content where you're brief, short answers where you're long-winded, etc.).

Before you pour a ton of resources into on-page improvements, I'd dig through the search results for the topic you're targeting and see who owns that space—and why (e.g., super powerful domain, niche site speaking to their expertise, long-form content where you're brief, short answers where you're long-winded, etc.).

text: We have a fairly authoritative domain, and currently we use ranking position 5-20 if its been live for at least 6 months as "underperforming"

elements.text: We have a fairly authoritative domain, and currently we use ranking position 5-20 if its been live for at least 6 months as "underperforming"

text:
Makes sense. If it's scalable, I'd still encourage folks from your team to take a peek at the SERP before diving into an on-page revision.

Plenty of SERPs out there with fractured intent where, for example, only a few of the results on Page 1 are really "up for grabs" from informational content (or vice versa)—so ranking sixth may actually be the top or second-to-top spot for an informational page.

Or, maybe someone realizes that the topic is at the fringe of _your_ expertise and Google is rewarding smaller sites that really hone in on the niche.

When you are doing the on-page updates, I've found it best to lean into the existing inertia, which you can usually spot in Google Search Console. If it's already showing you for a subtopic, you're often better off—in my experience—shaping the article to address it. I've had little luck changing Google's mind once it's been made up.

text: Makes total sense! I think the trouble we're running into is reporting outcomes...somestimes our intervensions work and sometimes they don't. When they do, we get a lot of questions from say, product folks, about what exactly we changed so we can scale that across all articles. Except (to many of your points), its kind of hard to pick out one thing that worked when you're optimizing holistically--especially when that thing may not be what all articles need RE: SERP analysis, intent, etc. Any advice on managing those kinds of stakeholder questions?

elements.text: Makes total sense! I think the trouble we're running into is reporting outcomes...somestimes our intervensions work and sometimes they don't. When they do, we get a lot of questions from say, product folks, about what exactly we changed so we can scale that across all articles. Except (to many of your points), its kind of hard to pick out one thing that worked when you're optimizing holistically--especially when that thing may not be what all articles need RE: SERP analysis, intent, etc. Any advice on managing those kinds of stakeholder questions?

text: Expectation setting? "Based on the formula we use for updating posts (i.e. positions 5-20 after 6 months) we've seen that on-page updates improve performance X% of the time. Other times, on-page optimization is not the difference between current positions and a top 5 position. Posts improve incrementally, for various reasons—a little better keyword targeting, a few more links, a little bit longer in search results, etc. Because of this, we never know *exactly* why a post improves."

elements.text: Expectation setting? "Based on the formula we use for updating posts (i.e. positions 5-20 after 6 months) we've seen that on-page updates improve performance X% of the time. Other times, on-page optimization is not the difference between current positions and a top 5 position. Posts improve incrementally, for various reasons—a little better keyword targeting, a few more links, a little bit longer in search results, etc. Because of this, we never know
exactly
why a post improves."

text:
When we go through old pieces, we run them through Clearscope and find that even pieces that we optimized 6 months earlier are now missing keywords and some topics that they should now include. We also review the other competitors to figure out where we've missed the simple stuff, like related Google questions, sections relevant to the topic, or visuals that will add value.

We've also started being pickier with how we link internally. If an article is underperforming, we'll often remove a lot of links to categories less closely related to the main topic, and link more to the very closely related pieces on their site.

text: Use <http://Lumen5.com|Lumen5.com> to turn articles into videos with the text of the article laid over B-roll. You can also record a voiceover if you like. Then upload the video to YouTube and then embed it back in the original article.

elements.text: Use
Lumen5.com

to turn articles into videos with the text of the article laid over B-roll. You can also record a voiceover if you like. Then upload the video to YouTube and then embed it back in the original article.

text: My friend wanted to know if there’s a tool where you copy your content and it tells you what the focus keyword should be. I couldn’t think of one. I know there are tools where you tell it the focus keyword and then copy your content to see if it’s “optimized.”

elements.text: My friend wanted to know if there’s a tool where you copy your content and it tells you what the focus keyword should be. I couldn’t think of one. I know there are tools where you tell it the focus keyword and then copy your content to see if it’s “optimized.”

text: I'd also argue that trying to get above position 5 can even be impossible in some keywords - ie, Wikipedia or Capterra might be above you and you won't be able to beat them - so some expectation setting around which posts can even be further optimized at all might be part of the conversation

text:
By underperforming I’d imagine you mean less organic traffic in Google, right? Then, apart from everything that was just said, I’d look at natural language processing tools and libraries (<https://cloud.google.com/natural-language|google’s one is a great start>, in the Try the Api box, you can paste a lot before you get prompted to make an account), and try to see whether the overall article’s relation to the actual topic is high, or whether each of the paragraphs’ topic is correlated with the paragraph text For example, if i’m speaking in the article too much about car parts and my article topic is on car repairs and i want to rank for the latter, the salience gets scrambled. Here’s a cool short-ish guide on the topic - <https://www.gainchanger.com/how-to-leverage-google-nlp-for-seo/>.

I wouldn’t go too crazy on that and start writing super robotic - that’s not good - just look at some of the paragraphs, what entities inside them are recognized, and overall - whether the article is qualified in the “right category”. Perhaps some of the wording takes it way off topic. Or as it was said above, we need to up the relevance and tools like Clearscope and Topic help with uncovering those. You can also plug the competitor articles into Google NLP tool to see what topics they are being related to. Then, it’s you who has to choose what exactly to change, knowing your niche and what makes most sense for your readers.

attachments.title: Cloud Natural Language  |  Google Cloud
attachments.text: Analyze text with AI using pre-trained API or custom AutoML machine learning models to extract relevant entities, understand sentiment, and more.
attachments.fallback: Google Cloud: Cloud Natural Language  |  Google Cloud

attachments.title: How to Leverage Google NLP in SEO - GainChanger
attachments.text: Read our overview of the the basics of Natural Language Processing and how you can leverage Google NLP for your SEO strategy
attachments.fallback: GainChanger: How to Leverage Google NLP in SEO - GainChanger

text:
One way is hreflang tags and rewriting bits of your content with the local variation of the English language if any, but i’ve seen people implement hreflang tags and other language URLs (like subfolders, subdomains and so on) by the book, and Google still scrambles everything, so I can’t recommend the best way to go about this, there’s always a risk.

Besides, the more you grow in your main market, the rest will follow, arguably, they’ll follow similar ratio you already have with the keywords.

Besides, the more you grow in your main market, the rest will follow, arguably, they’ll follow similar ratio you already have with the keywords.

text: Topic is another tool I’ve used. You could also plug in the content in Google NLP tool and see what topics it will highlight.
